R E C T E D P
It is becoming progressively more understandable that sensitivity and versatility of magnetic biosensors provides unique platform for high performance diagnostics in clinical settings. Confluence of information suggested that magnetic biosensors required well-tailored magnetic particles as probes for detection that generate large and specific biological signal with minimum possible nonspecific binding. However, there are visible knowledge gaps in our understanding of the strategies to overcome existing challenges related to even smaller size of intracellular targets and lower signal-to-noise ratio than that in whole-cell studies, therefore tool designing and development for intracellular measurement and manipulation is problematic. In this review we describe magnetic nanoparticles, synthesis and sensing principles of magnetic nanoparticles as well as surface functionalization and modification and finally magnetic nanoparticles for medical diagnostics. This review gathers important and up-to-date information and may help to develop the method of obtaining magnetic materials especially for medical application. © 2016 Published by Elsevier Inc.

sections.heading: Magnetic nanoparticles
sections.text: To understand a behavior of magnetic particles it is necessary to determine their physicochemical parameters such as size, shape and magnetic properties. Three types of magnetic particles can be distinguished and they are as follows: oxides, metallic metals and alloys. They exhibit various magnetic properties. The oxides tended to possess antiferromagnetic or fluctuating magnetic properties. Metals are magnetic, however, the nature of their magnetic properties depends on size and morphology of their particles. Alloys on the other hand tend to have characteristics that are a combination of the magnetic properties of the metals they are composed of.

sections.heading: Oxides
sections.text:
The first type of magnetic particles that needs to be considered is oxides. He and Shi31 stated that, “CoO in bulk is regarded as an insulating antiferromagnet with rocksalt cubic structure and Neếl temperature of 298 K”. There are two important magnetic particles that are in oxide form, FeO and Co3O4. One of the most important characteristics ofCo3O4 is that itsmagnetic properties are changing under different conditions. Gawali et al32 found that, the vibration sample magnetometer (VSM) data of nanoparticles exhibit weak ferromagnetic properties with magnetic saturation of about 0.02 emu/g at the maximummagnetic field of 10 kOe, whereas material in bulk shows antiferromagnetic properties. When cobalt (II,III) oxide is exposed to amagnetic field it acts like a typicalmagnet and displays weak ferromagnetic behavior. However, a sample of Co3O4 not exposed to magnetic field will display antiferromagnetic behavior. Also, CoO seems to possess variable magnetic properties. He and Shi31 found that, the CoO nanoparticles possess anomalous magnetic properties, such as large movements, coercivities and loop shifts. These features determine the formation of spin compensation of random system inCoO. These findings are important because they suggest that the magnetic properties of

sections.heading: Metallic
sections.text: There are a number of metallic particles that have magnetic properties. Considering the properties of nickel (Ni), He et al33 explained that: “The transition metal such as nickel exhibits particular magnetic and catalytic properties”. This suggests that Ni is a metal that have a unique magnetic and catalytic properties. Size and organization mode of Ni particles affect their magnetic properties. Deraz34 found, that high value of magnetization of the studied materials can be correlated with a finite-size and surface effect. Particularly, the magnetization is correlated with the microstructure of the interface (roughness and crystallinity degree) that determines the configuration of the spin. These findings suggest that morphology of the Ni, Ni lattices and compounds that contain Ni particles determines their magnetic properties. Various morphological structures of materials containing Ni affect their behavior and even result in changes of the surface area of Ni particles. Many reports state that the size of the particle affects properties of Ni. According to He et al33 “…the Curie temperature, saturation magnetization, and remanent magnetization increase whereas the coercivity decreases monotonously with the increase of particle size”. This may suggest that the larger Ni may be characterized by higher levels of saturation and remanent magnetization.

Alloys are combinations of atoms of different metals. When discussing the process of making Fe56Co7Ni7B20Nb10 alloy Lesz et al35 explain that the Fe-based master alloy ingots can be formed by melting the mixtures of Fe–B and Fe–Nb as starting alloys and accordingly Fe, Co, or Ni are added metals under protective atmosphere of inert gas such as argon. Such synthetic route leads to the formation of Fe56Co7Ni7B20Nb10 and a large number alloys that exhibit the complex nature with wide range of properties. The combination of metals in Fe56Co7Ni7B20Nb10 results in a combination of morphological, chemical and physical characteristics of the material. Lesz et al35 reported, that the XRD and TEM structural and morphological analyses showed that the ribbons obtained were amorphous. SEM micrographs depicted some structural differences in the ribbons (smooth fracture inside with few grains network on the surface freely solidified). Consequently, the material exhibits various physical and chemical properties at different locations. Also, the magnetic properties of such alloy exhibit its heterogeneous nature. Analyzing such structure Lutz et al36 reported that Ni was always superparamagnetic, while Co possessed superparamagnetism only at low temperatures. Fe56Co7Ni7B20Nb10 seems to possess the magnetic properties derived from all the metals that form such structure. The formed alloys possess soft magnetic properties instead of the supermagnetic ones, observed in metals such as Ni. sections.heading: Magnetic nanoparticles—methods of preparation
sections.text:
The pioneering synthesis utilizing alkaline co-precipitation from FeCl3 and FeCl2 that resulted in the formation of 8 nm magnetic nanoparticles was performed for the first time by Massart 23 in 1981. The nanostructure obtained was black in color. Precipitation of Fe3O4 was carried out in non-oxidizing environment, within pH of 8-14 at Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio equal to 2:1.37 Non-oxidizing environment was created by passing the inert gas such as N2 to control kinetics of the oxidation of iron and to reduce the particle size of the species.21,38 Size, shape and composition of magnetic nanoparticles are strictly correlated with the type of salts used during synthesis, the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio, the temperature of reaction, pH value and ionic strength of the media. Ambient temperature of the synthesis results in the formation of poorly crystalline structures that require further annealing. On the contrary, process performed at elevated temperature leads to the formation of well crystallized metal oxides. It is of a great importance to stabilize mixture of nanoparticles by introducing a dispersing agent such as anionic surfactant into reaction medium. Surfactants with various properties can be employed to stabilize nanoparticles in suspension. Depending on the nature of the counter ions, pH and ionic strength the nanoparticles can be stabilized via interactions between electrically charged double layers. The concentration of inert electrolyte that surrounds the double layer of colloidal nanostructures may promote coagulation.
One of the new methods of synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles is application of microemulsions. Schulman in 1959 in his pioneering work proposed application of microemulsion synthesis using four component system solution system containing water, benzene, hexanol and K-oleate. Recently Drmota et al27 reported synthesis of maghemite ɣ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles via in situ precipitation in two microemulsion systems. The proposed microemulsion system comprised water solution of Fe+2/Fe+3 ions, aqueous solution of NH4OH, anionic surfactant such as SDS, butanol used as co-surfactant and cyclohexane—as an oil phase. The synthesis of nanoparticles was performed at the same water-to-surfactant or co-surfactant molar ratio. The final stage of the synthesis leads to oxidation of the Fe(II) hydroxide and subsequent production of spinel maghemite (ɣ-Fe2O3). Then, the surface of ɣ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles formed by microemulsion was covered with tetraethoxysilane (TEOS). The effect of parameters such as: concentration of reactants in aqueous phase, the temperature, pH value after precipitation on the formation of maghemite ɣ-Fe2O3 was evaluated. Okoli and co-workers26 reported synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles via w/o microemulsion method where the two different microemulsion systems were investigated. Both microemulsion systems comprised a surfactant, cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), co-surfactant, oil phase, iron precursors (FeCl2 and FeCl3), precipitating agent and water.

O F Sensing principles of magnetic nanoparticles
Magnetic sensors are working according to the principle: magnetic moment is changing in magnetic materials when they are subjected to a magnetic field, but in magneto elastic materials the magnetic moment is changing when they are exposed to mechanical stress generated by the medium in which they are immersed. By performing measurement of such variations the changes in the surroundings can be analyzed. In biomedical applications the magnetic sensors are considered for analysis of blood, cerebrospinal fluid, culture medium or organic tissue. In all cases the undesirable interactions between the medium fluids and magnetic material have been observed. The organic media may be damaged by non-biocompatible magnetic materials such as transition metals and their ions, but the compatible iron constitutes an exceptional material biocompatible with various human organs, tissues which exhibit great affinity to iron. The medium fluids mentioned above include several ions such as Cl−, Ca2+, Na+, K+. They are corrosive for magnetic materials. This lack of biocompatibility can be minimized by coating with thin layers of a biocompatible material such as gold, platinum, titanium oxide, silica or alumina. The coating can be performed using evaporation, sputtering, electrolysis and ionic implantation methods. The parts of magnetic sensors can be made of ceramics, medical silicones or silica. Recently, wireless transmission facilitates applied as internal and mainly external implants have become very convenient for patient's movements. Nowadays a great progress in using cellular phones, combined with magnetic sensors and biosensors, allowed for development of “telediagnosis”.57 Magnetic nanoparticles due to strong magnetic properties are widely applied as a source of labels in biosensing and moreover in modification of size, composition, electric and magnetic properties. That allows for their utilization as formats for sensing and biosensing.58 Recently, a great effort has been devoted to design biodetection system composed of magnetic nanoparticles with magnetoresistive (MR) sensors.59 The main concept of building such systems has been based on an attachment of magnetic nanoparticles to the molecules analyzed and subsequent use of magnetic sensors to detect stray field generated by nanoparticles incorporated (NPs).60 Shen et al have proposed the formation of the MgO-based magnetic tunnel junction sensors for detection of DNA labeled with magnetic nanoparticles. sections.heading: Magnetic relaxation switches
sections.text:
Due to large surface area to volume ratio, magnetic and optic properties of nanoparticles find application as diagnostic tools for clinical use. Nanoparticles can be conjugated with various organic and inorganic ligands to provide affinity toward biological systems. Magnetic nanoparticles in contact with aqueous media magnify magnetic resonance of protons in water molecules. Notably, aggregation of magnetic particles accelerates dephasing of water protons thus leading to change in proton relaxation times (T2). Both, aggregation and dissociation of magnetic nanoparticle (MNP) clusters can be detected by a change in proton relaxation times (ΔT2) by applying techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or relaxometry. Formation of MNPs aggregates resulted in construction of magnetic relaxation switches (MRSw). Such reversible switches can be used to detect DNA, bacteria, viruses or other bio-objects. In addition, detection based onMRSw is independent of light properties such as scattering and auto-fluorescence. The detection of biological samples based on MRSw constitutes an alternative strategy to commonly used switches.70 Cha and coworkers71 noted that magnetic nanocluster (MNC) could be used as an efficient probe for the MRSw assay. Concentration of streptavidin at the surface of magnetic nanoclusters conjugated with polyacrylic acid can be determined using MRSw assays. Figure 2 exemplifies the MRSw assay.

sections.heading: Magnetoresistive sensors

Magnetoresistance is the changeable electronic resistance of material exposed to magnetic field. This phenomenon was primarily discovered by William Thomson in 1851. Such effect was determined as ordinary magnetoresistance (OMR) in order to distinguish it from more recent discoveries of giant magnetoresistance (GMR), colossal magnetoresistance (CMR), tunnel magnetoresistance (TMR) and extraordinary magnetoresistance (EMR). Recently, researchers from Princeton University discovered a semimetal such as tungsten ditelluride, which possesses magnetoresistance equal to 13,000,000%. Generally, resistance can depend either on magnetization or directly on magnetic field.75 William Thomson also analyzed a phenomenon known as anisotropic magnetoresistance (AMR). In his studies pieces of iron were applied. The observations indicated that when the current and magnetic force were having the same direction the increase of resistance was observed, whereas, when their directions were differing by 90o the resistance was decreasing. This author performed similar studies also with other metals such as nickel.

Resistivity and ferroelectric properties of barium titanate loaded polymeric nanocomposites are not in correlation with space charge of BaTiO3/polymeric interfaces. sections.heading: Chemical functionalization of surfaces
sections.text:
Iron oxide nanoparticles without coatings are generally unstable and undergo leaching. That limits strongly their application. The large surface area to volume ratio leads to a reduction in surface energy of nanoparticles and thus results in formation of aggregates of particles. To overcome these limitations various approaches can be used to modify surfaces of magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) during or after synthesis process. The coating of magnetic nanoparticle (MNP) techniques not only promotes biocompatibility of MNPs but also provides converting of hydrophobic iron oxide nanoparticles into hydrophilic systems.99 Wet precipitation synthesis of magnetic nanoparticles involves mixing of iron salts with sodium hydroxide. Magnetic nanoparticles obtained are usually negatively charged, susceptible to agglomeration in solution. The external coatings lead to introduction of functional groups that are conjugated to the surface ofmagnetic nanoparticles. The vastly applied coatings can be briefly divided into two major groups: coatings with organic shells that involve polymers or coating with inorganic components such as silica, carbon, noble metals such as silver and gold. In general, surfactants or polymers can be chemically anchored or physically adsorbed on magnetic nanoparticles to form a layered structure that leads to repulsive forces (steric repulsion) stabilizing the magnetic nanoparticles in solution.100 The preferable polymer for surface modification should be biocompatible and have high affinity toward the surface of nanoparticles. After introducing the functionalized nanoparticles into the contact with blood plasma fluids, such functionalization of hydrophobic nanoparticles with hydrophilic polymers should prevent interaction with plasma proteins and increase in vivo circulation; coating makes nanoparticles multifunctional, in conjugation with drugs, genes, or imaging agents. Also, surface coating ofmagnetic nanoparticles prevents from agglomeration and cytotoxicity and introduces additional functional groups. Surfactants such as oleic acid, lauric acid, alkylsulfonic acids, and alkylphosphonic acids are commonly used molecules.101

sections.heading: Fluorescent nanoparticles
sections.text:
The term imaging has many different meanings or interpretations. Imaging is a form of photography in many people's perception.108 Scientific imaging on the other hand is highly developed compared to imaging. Fluorescence based imaging has gained a lot of interest because it has spectroscopies that are selective, sensitive and rich in versatility and contrast. The availability of fluorescent nanomaterials for purposes of imaging has given rise to a variety of methods for imaging with features that include brightness and inertness to their microenvironment.
Most fluorescent nanoparticles (NPs) that include semiconductor QuantumDots, metal NPs, polymer NPs and silica NPs have been a major focus of research and study in the past decade. The fluorescent nanoparticles have unique chemical and optical properties, for instance brighter fluorescence, higher biocompatibility and photostability compared to classical fluorescent organic dyes.109 The NPs can function as multivalent scaffolds to effect supramolecular assemblies because their high surface to volume ratio allows distinct spatial domains to be functionalized. This proves a versatile synthetic platform to ensure different sensing schemes occur. Fluorescent nanoparticle-based imaging has helped in the development of current labeling technology and is expected to contribute toward the generation of newmedical diagnostic tools based on their superior brightness.110 An example of fluorescent nanoparticles includes Quantum Dots (QDs).111 These semiconductor nanocrystals are emerging as a novel class of multifunctional fluorescent probes for many potential biological and medical applications. When compared to conventional organic fluorescent dyes, they have many advantages such as narrow emission and broadband excitation and extended half-life. Because QDs are made from semiconductor materials, their optical properties are influenced by the link between electrons, environments and holes. Semiconductor materials take photons when absorbance energy goes beyond the difference of the conduction band energy and valence.112

Through controlling the coating, size and composition of QDs, the emission wavelength can be tuned from the ultraviolent to the infrared region. The properties of QDs are essential in the enhancement of the sensitivity of molecular histopathology and diagnosis of certain diseases. However, QDs have also been found to have certain limitations.113 For instance, QDs have potential toxicity that has made them be excluded from in vivo imaging applications. Because of the properties that QDs have, they are excellent for use as FRET partners that can be used for biosensing both in medical and biological processes. However, it is important to mention that their ability to transfer their excited energy to a partner is still not understood and this provides another limitation to their usage.114
When compared to molecular dyes, nanoparticles are not cytotoxic and do not react negatively to nonspecific binding through cellular biomacromolecules or unwanted sequencing. Dyed fluorescent nanoparticles hardly interact with cellular proteins and are not affected by the proteins outside them. This explains why nanoparticles have photostabilities that are better to molecular problems.115 In addition, many fluorescent nanoparticles can easily be put into cells and tissues and be used to target specific sites. However, this is always dependent on their surface chemistry and charge. For example, a positively charged nanoparticle will facilitate quick internalization. Compared to fluorescent proteins, fluorescent nanoparticles are simple to handle and provide predictable results. In addition, many of them are commercially available and provide a way of handling many cell lines simultaneously because of their simplicity in loading and labeling with fluorophores.116
Silica nanoparticles (SiNPs) were among the first ones to be used in bio-imaging. For instance, mesoporous silica is often used because they can be heavily loaded with fluorescent dyes. SiNPs can also be easily doped with different types of organic, metal organic, emission wavelengths and fluophores. They can also be doped with luminescence lanthanides to make them have features such as long decay times that provide time-resolved flyorometry and efficiency in background suppression.
Hydrophilic materials for use in NP-based imaging include hydrogels and natural products, for instance cellulose. Nanogels are soft and water soluble. NPs from organic monomers can be linked with other partners to make them swellable and soluble. They can be used for NP-assisted drug delivery.117

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
Recently a great attention has been devoted toward the formation of biosensors on the basis of magnetic nanoparticles. To understand the role of magnetic particles it is necessary to determine their physicochemical parameters such as size, shape, magnetic properties. Three types of magnetic particles can be distinguished and they are as follows: oxides, metallics and alloys. Each of these types of magnetic particles has different physical, mechanical and chemical properties. They also exhibit various magnetic properties. The oxides tend to possess antiferromagnetic or fluctuating magnetic properties. On the contrary, metals are magnetic but, the nature of their magnetic properties depends on the size and morphology of these particles. Alloys on the other hand tend to have characteristics that are a combination of the magnetic properties of the metals they are composed of.

An example of fluorescent nanoparticles includes Quantum Dots (QDs).(111) These semiconductor nanocrystals are emerging as a novel class of multifunctional fluorescent probes for many potential biological and medical applications.

Semiconductor materials take photons when absorbance energy goes beyond the difference of the conduction band energy and valence.(112) E D P R O O F Through controlling the coating, size and composition of QDs, the emission wavelength can be tuned from the ultraviolent to the infrared region.
However, QDs have also been found to have certain limitations.(113) For instance, QDs have potential toxicity that has made them be excluded from in vivo imaging applications.

However, it is important to mention that their ability to transfer their excited energy to a partner is still not understood and this provides another limitation to their usage.(114) When compared to molecular dyes, nanoparticles are not cytotoxic and do not react negatively to nonspecific binding through cellular biomacromolecules or unwanted sequencing.

This explains why nanoparticles have photostabilities that are better to molecular problems.(115) In addition, many fluorescent nanoparticles can easily be put into cells and tissues and be used to target specific sites.

In addition, many of them are commercially available and provide a way of handling many cell lines simultaneously because of their simplicity in loading and labeling with fluorophores.(116) Silica nanoparticles (SiNPs) were among the first ones to be used in bio-imaging.
They can be used for NP-assisted drug delivery.(117)

Immunoassay is defined as biochemical test that detects and measures concentration of antigens recognized by antibodies such as immunoglobulins formed by immune system to protect organism against infections.(118) Immunoassay test is based on the ability of antibody to recognize and bind specific antigen forming the immune complex.

The magnetic field changes, induced by magnetic particles, are subsequently detected by magnetic reader such as magnetometer.(119) For immunoassay application magnetic nanoparticles can be utilized as both labels of antigens or antibodies or as solid phase technology that the antibody can be immobilized on the surface.

Magnetic nanoparticles can be employed in immunoassay due to their magnetic properties enabling easy separation and concentration in large volumes.(120) Another type of magnetic immunoassay is determined as enzyme immunoassay method utilized for isolation of antigen–antibody complexes on a surface of magnetic nanoparticles.

They are more effective in acceleration and the separation and also improve sensitivity over commonly applied assays.(121) Chatterjee et al(122) reported on application of maghemite nanoparticles as immunoassay in solid phases that were subsequently detected by Supecronducting Quantum Interface Device (SQUID).

Confluence of information suggested that magnetic biosensors required well-tailored magnetic particles as probes for detection that generate large and specific biological signal with minimum possible nonspecific binding. However, there are visible knowledge gaps in our understanding of the strategies to overcome existing challenges related to even smaller size of intracellular targets and lower signal-to-noise ratio than that in whole-cell studies, therefore tool designing and development for intracellular measurement and manipulation is problematic. In this review we describe magnetic nanoparticles, synthesis and sensing principles of magnetic nanoparticles as well as surface functionalization and modification and finally magnetic nanoparticles for medical diagnostics.
